ratings.comment: If this class was not required, I would 100% not have taken it. It's all online lectures and he really could care less about his students. Not responsive at all with questions - even specifically said in an email once NOT to ask him any questions. He clearly does not care about the students or the class. (Also, watch online lectures at 2x speed!!)

All online lectures. Never once met him, but in lectures he kind of talks in circles. The material is fairly hard/requires a lot of studying in order to really be able to understand & apply the topics to real life scenarios. Use the practice problems! The exams have curves that really help. Attendance at discussion counts for a percentage of grade.

All online lectures. However, he is not very approachable about course administration questions. Online lectures are very slow and dry, so be sure to watch at 2x. Discussion sections are a must if you're looking to do well on exams.

The class is online but that's probably for the best. Avoid talking to him because he seriously doesn't care about any of his students. I let him know there was a glitch in the computer that caused an entire one of my short answer questions to erase with less than a minute left and all he could manage to tell me is there was nothing he could do.

Bruce is an instructor who seems to be very experienced in his field. Online lectures are sometimes entertaining, although it feels like there are hundreds of them. Textbook is too pricey for how much reading he assigns, so you are better off saving your money. In order to do well, just watch all of his lectures and follow the course packet.

Harms is a straightforward guy teaching a straightforward course. You don't need to go to class, but it does help you keep pace with the material. Exams are pretty demanding and require a lot of memorization, but two nights before, max, is all you need. Remember to study the cases and past essays are key. It's really not as bad as everyone says.

It's all been said. Harms is a very straightforward lecturer who follows his outline and gives helpful examples now and then. His sarcastic sense of humor helps. You will learn a ton in this class. Walsh is very helpful at preparing you for exams. Study lots a few days beforehand and you'll do just fine. Class really isn't that bad, relax people.

Very tough professor. Hard, mean, not willing to help. No questions in class, doesn't really care if students understand material as long as he gets through it. Exams are super specific and tougher than they need be, especially for a general course that so many non-law students need to take.

Outline is well-organized, lecture is always clear and well-presented, and there are plenty of long digressions. Basically, Harms teaches like the experienced lawyer he is. Tough attitude: no questions in class and expectation in discussion that you've done the reading. Exams are fair but tough, requiring studying and good grasp of the material.
Harms says that this class is to give you an overview of law, but the questions on exams are incredibly specific. This class is much harder than needs to be. Also Lectures are pointless to attend.

You probably won't have a choice concerning this class. Hard to get an A, easy (and probable) to get a B. Take Walsh for discussion. Use outline to study, try to review often as opposed to right before exam. Make sure you can nail the essay questions on exams.
The class is pretty much a B for a majority of the students (large curve).  No need to go to class just look at the outline and use the book for cases.

A tough class, but I really learned a lot (and even put it to use!). I had to study a lot and work very hard, and managed a B. It's required, but worth it. Make sure to take Walsh as your TA- he's awesome.

This class is pretty difficult, but I learned SO much. The class outline is incredibly helpful, but the tests aren't easy by any means. I studied for days before the exams and got a B. It's a required class so be prepared to work for a B

You will learn a ton in this class. It's not easy, but if you stay caught up with reading and start studying several days in advanced, you'll be fine. Basically memorize the outline and practice problems, tests are very similar. Harms is funny in an old grumpy man sort of way. Discussion with DeWitt was useless most of time, I hear Walsh is better.
dont need to attend lecture ever. just read the cases, outlines and text and TAKE WALSH as your TA

Good professor. Doesn't let students ask questions in lecture, which is great for students who have actually come prepared to class and who don't want to listen to the silly questions of idiots. This should be a rule in all lectures. Tests are tricky but not that bad. Read the book and follow the outline and you'll get no worse than a B.

Look, Harms (and this class) isn't as terrible as everyone says.  Yeah, he can be pretty longwinded but in the long run I find his stories helpful.  Take Walsh as your TA, he is remarkably helpful.  You just need to make sure to spend a good couple of days really going over the material and the tests will be fine.

If you enjoy  not being able to understand a professors' notes, and he makes no sense grammatically, and completely throws you off with sentences that contradict each other,take business law. The book is just fine, but have fine trying to apply that knowledge to the incomprehensible jargon you are forced to somehow know for his exams.

Harms is a great professor. Very funny and entertaining. Read the cases and study from the class notes, and you should do well on the exams. Know how to apply concepts to diff. scenarios. Discussion helps! Make sure to get John Walsh if you can, he's the man! Harms & TA's are all real life lawyers, so you will definitely get a lot out of this class

Now I know why lawyers are the most reviled people on the planet. RIDICULOUS CURVE. Like 88-86 for an AB; compare 42-72 for a C! I'm sorry, but if you got a 42% you should get an F. If you have plans for law school, don't let his tests deter you from this passion.
Good prof. Tests require a lot of preparation. READ THE BOOK. His personality isn't bad, a lot of kids just aren't used to someone outside of academia. Besides teaching he practices law.
I liked this class a lot. Most people thought it was hard: if you do the reading and have a brain you will be fine.
Great professor. If you follow his outline you'll be set.
Not helpful, rude, and blatantly does not care about the people in his class.

Makes some funny jokes but sorry not enough! Condescending towards students, rude in office, writes ridiculously worded tests, essays are graded pretty inconsistently. I wouldn't recommend him unless you are required to take this class.

This guy will kickstart your brain early in the morning with his caffinated personality.  He's ruthless in his exams, and he'll inform you of your impending F with a "what can you do?" gesture.  Close your eyes, and you'd swear you were attending a lecture by Gordon Gekko from Wall Street!!
If you like to think, take this course.  If you are a lazy idiot like most students, do nit
This class is pretty difficult, be willing to work hard, but it is doable.
